comments.commentBody: No need. Kitty Kelley said it better than I ever could.
Romance is a lovely excuse, but they were definitely out to rescue the man!

Once again, Maggie Smith and Penelope Wilton steal the show. A wedding (predictable), the Bates Babe (predictable), Mary preggers (predictable), but  kidnapping a man from his family for romance--bravo!
Not to mention Catherine in the 1973 West End production of Pippin.

As Jay65 (do not understand how my moniker got changed by NYTimes),

Talk to the moniker maker, Monica. She makes monikers.

The British rank is: King/Queen > Prince/Princess > Duke/Duchess > Marquess/Marchioness > Earl/Countess > Viscount/Viscountess > Baron/Baroness > Baronet

So Edith, Marchioness of Hexham, outranked her parents and her sister. Mary was married to, lost and then bore the next male heir to Downton Abbey, who will become the new Earl of Grantham if he survives beyond Robert's death, but I believe she at least retained the honorific "the Lady Mary Talbot" even after after marrying Talbot, since the daughter of an earl who marries a commoner still retains that courtesy.

Thanks (got my old title back!).  Does anyone remember if the Dowager Countess was herself the daughter of an Earl -- she did refer to her own father in the last episode.  Assuming Lord Robert survives, does anyone know what would happen, upon Robert's eventual death, to the estate following the reform of British property law a few years later?  Mary's son with Matthew would become an Earl, but would she get the house and land?  Unfortunately young Master George is the right age to be a junior officer in WWII or an RAF pilot.  Hope poor old Barrow doesn't wind up with a chart of his young charges who don't survive (as in another English show:  To Serve Them etc).

Very nice final wrap for Louis Bayard.  The real drinking game is how many times does a character in the Crawley family say:  let's go through or let's go up.  As Jay65 (do not understand how my moniker got changed by NYTimes), I was happy to be right in predicting one central fact and one that is merely a wisp of a hint:  Bertie came back; Tom and Miss Evans will get together very soon.  I learned that a Marquis outranks an Earl, or does one.  What precisely did Mary inherit from Matthew:  not the title of course, not Downton itself in 1925, so, merely his personalty, securities etc?   Patricia Hodge not only played the adulterous wife in Betrayal, but also the smart female barrister partner in Rumpole of the Bailey, no?  I watched the fund-raiser afterward:  character most missed from the Memorial segment (cannot believe they had Vera Bates in there):  Sybil of course.  Goodbye to All That.

Actually, I think this was very characteristic of Rose's sweet, resourceful and helpful nature.

Recall her lightning-quick bailout of her father-in-law when his former mistress showed up?

In addition, the delicious plot to steal back the Prince of Wales' letter?

I was so glad Rose made it into the finale.
To me, Rose always seemed to over-intrude, and I didn't like it this time any more than all the others.  It became understandable why her mother came down on her so much.

I was definitely taken aback by Rose's presumed role with Robert.  That, with his gosh-shucks reaction was so hokey.  Not long ago, Rose was the juvenile delinquent in the house and in London.  They had to drag her out of bars, etc. to keep her from ruining her own London season.  For her to come barging in from across the ocean, no longer a household member, supplanting the daughters and all to undertake to set the head of the house straight ... really obnoxious.  Actually, it was the same cheek she always demonstrated.

Nicely tidied up. I was singing Auld Lang Syne along with the staff. I will miss them all.

Only thing I could have done without was Lady Rose giving life advice to Robert. Isn't she 19?

Thank you Mr. Bayard.
As a lady's maid, Anna was not in a position to demand requirements for keeping such a secret. Loyalty and discretion are inherent to her job.

Anna never confronted Lady Mary with her requirements for keeping the whole business about Mr. Pamook under wraps.   I'd been looking  forward to that scene all these years.  But thanks to you, Mr. Bayard, and the rest of your community of followers.
just wait for the symbols!
It's like in Hitchcock's "The 39 Steps" - wait for the clash of the symbols...
Oops, of course that was "The Man Who Knew Too Much" - I mix them up because the stage act in 39 steps involves - knowing too much!
Where in the Crossword Apps is the fine print indicating a clue (or two) could be a number?
If you mean Upstairs, Downstairs, there already was a part deux.In
Until then. Your commentary enabled me to have informed conversations with my wife about her favorite program. Well done.
Then why did you watch? It took six years to figure that out?
Back to bitter reality for you. Give me some escapist entertainment. Loved it.
It was too sweet for my taste.
These are good points, but China's biggest problem is its unreasonable growth target. More patience is needed.

Shocking! Shocking! Absolutely shocking! I dare write, that there is not a high school teacher in any of the major subjects, who hasn't seen these college image and money makers, coddled and given a free ride in their subjects, without any mastery of the content those teachers teach! But to cry out, would mean putting their jobs at stake, and they have to go along with the system! That's just the way it is....College is big business today! Don't be fooled!

If I were the writer of this article I would be embarrassed to show my face in the news room. Why? Because I obviously missed the story.

The story is, what's this kid, Fraizier, who's obviously no Einstein, doing in a physics class in High School. Solve that problem an you just about solve every other "problem" hyperbolicated in the article.

I thought I read this article fairly carefully. Somehow I missed the paragraph where Mr. Frazier takes some responsibility for his own academic and personal failures.
Coach Brown has a sleazy history which SMU was apparently comfortable with. No tears for the school or the team.
But the bottom line remains: we are all responsible for our own behavior and choices. This includes the players. Otherwise we're just patronizing and profiling them.

In the last few years, the NCAA has been disproportunately penal in acadenic misconduct cases, no matter if isolated, as the Fraiser matter, a single incident involving just one player. In Brown's case, the NCAA neither found Brown complicite in the act itself, nor for failing to report the incident ito the proper authorities, which he did. They punished him with a 9 game penalty for reporting the incident belatedly, and for lying during an NCAA interrogation , and then correcting his answer after consulting his arrorney .

Brown is not the only Big Time coach to get slammed for academic fraud violations recently. I don't mean to imply Brown was unfairly singled out (although I'd like to know who dropped the dime, and whether the dime included allegations of widespread violations for which there was no proof)

Either way, it seems undeniable that the NCAA has been quite vigilant and punative in recent times with respect to academic fraud, except if it's epidenic and the violator UNC ( wink).

My question is this. Is this vigilance essential to the NCAA's insistence that players who are obliged to work year-round are not emplouees, because they are STUDENT athletes, whatever that means, a claim that there seems to be consensus here is pure myth.

Without that vigilance, the NCAA's postion becomes a one-footed stool, right. So, is this more proof that the NCAA needs to go? "Not a soup question, now is it."
And dangerous to other skiers around them....

Sorry, and glad you lived through it.  My son compressed three vertebrae while snowboarding.  Still impacts his work ten years later.  He was not a beginner either.  He had skied and snowboarded for ten years before the accident.  Skied like a wild man and was never hurt.  Not even a muscle strain.
Though I am sorry to hear about your injury, it's tough to say that people choose skiing vs snowboarding based on risk of concussions. Wouldn't both present an equal risk?

The article doesn't mention the role of concussions in snowboarding's fall in popularity. A lifetime skier, my concussion while learning to snowboard cost me a half-year's wages and took a toll on my family. (Yes, I was wearing a helmet). When you fall on a snowboard, it HURTS. The sport may be dangerous at any speed.

Weather (and ridiculously high lift tickets) has definitely been an issue.

The bigger deal for snowboarding companies is lack of technology advancement. If you have modern boots with one of several types of speed laces, you're set (last 10 years). A modern board (high quality - 15 years), you're set. Bindings have gotten better recently (last 5 years you're set). Sure if you're boarding 100 days/year your replacement rate will be somewhat quicker. But most people are boarding less than 10 days/year and only need new equipment every 5-10 years (with lots of ebay used equipment available too).

I feel bad for the pros left out in the cold, but right now pro snowboarding (2-3 runs/day) has little relevance to the boards, boots, and bindings recreational boarders use for a 6 hour snow day.

Not for me.  I ski raced for years when I was a kid, but when snowboarding came along, I found I enjoyed it more than skiing.  Maybe everyone is different, though I think the learning curve is shorter.

the learning curve to snowboard is a fraction of what it takes to ski.

that was and is still the main attraction.

2 edges vs. 4
Ski touring and ski mountaineering is where it's at!

Kiteboarding came along and made windsurfing obsolete. The article doesn't explain why snowboarding declined and why skiing had a resurgence. They mention the lack of snow in the West from the drought, but wouldn't that have impacted skiing as well?
The same thing happened with sailboarding around 20 years ago. The equipment market always gets flooded when a new sport springs up from nowhere.

For a 12-14 year old nothing kills off a lifestyle product faster than seeing your parents use it. Eeeeeewwwwww !
Snowboarding has been around long enough for that to happen.

Jones, Burton's Family Tree line, Gentem, United Shapes, Korua, Hightide, Venture, Prior, and more are all lines dedicated to making "all mountain" & freeride specific snowboards.

also, you're welcome for your modern shaped-ski performance.

When was the last time you looked at snowboard equipment? Every company now offers boards for every type of rider - new, young, older, everyone. Open your eyes and look around instead of typing what you want to believe!

No one to blame here but the companies themselves. For years they've marketed the sport exclusively to 12-14 year olds looking to do extreme tricks. They never stopped to think that those kids would eventually grow up and not want noodley freestyle boards adorned with often insulting, adolescent graphics. If they expand their market segment and design equipment for where and how people actually ride--and that can keep up with the performance of modern, shaped skis--they might have a chance to keep the sport relevant.

totally lame, subjective sport
more of a hobby really
just skateboarding on ice

comments.userLocation: up in the woods down by the river
comments.commentBody:
Skiing and snowboarding didn't used to be luxury sports. In the 70's we used to stay in a ski club bunkhouse in Vermont for $2 per night. Real estate development made a few people wealthy but ruined the sport for all but the very rich by jacking up the costs beyond reach for most people. Lift tickets are over $100/ day. Lodging is higher than that. The equipment is way overpriced.

Forget it. It's just not that much fun to drive that far and spend that much for a few runs under what are often poor weather and snow conditions. It's too bad because it was fun when it didn't cost a fortune. The whole industry jumped the shark.
Unfortunately, these days, there is less discretionary spending among teens through twenty-somethings, and snowboarding and Alpine skiing are expensive sports.
after high school, two of my friends moved to Utah to be ski bums. They washed dishes to pay for lift tickets.
Unfortunately snow sports are mainly for wealthy people. You won't find much sympathy with the majority of people. Guess they will have to get a job if Mom and Dad won't pay the bills.
You're correct on the lift ticket cost at Vail, however at NO OTHER MOUNTAIN is a lift ticket price that high. Overall most ski area lift tickets are well below half that cost in the US...
Maybe if a one day lift ticket didn't cost $175, the current price at Vail, both skiing and snowboarding would be more popular.
